abstracts.cdata!:
The outcome of the Second Shaanxi
            Provincial Highway Project for China was Satisfactory, the
            sustainability was likely, the institutional development
            impact was substantial, and the Bank and Borrower
            performance were both satisfactory. The major project
            components include five high-grade highways in five
            locations, and upgrading, improvement and construction of
            rural roads. The project tried to address all the key
            transport sector issues in China. During the phase
            preparation in 1994 and 1995, the Shaanxi Provincial
            Transport Department was keen to develop the proposed
            components, but soon it was overwhelmed with other projects
            funded by other banks. The agency was overstretched in its
            capacity to implement various projects and experienced
            severe shortage of qualified staff. The Roads Improvement
            for Poverty Alleviation program demonstrated positive
            contribution towards poverty alleviation and in providing a
            basic road access for social services and markets. The
            technical complexity of highway construction and operations
            was underestimated. This component experienced substantial
            costs overruns. Changes in design and variations could have
            been avoided or minimized if designs had been based on more
            accurate topographic maps and results of geotechnical
            investigations during the project preparation.
